TechWaterloo brings together the Waterloo Region's tech leaders, innovators, and enthusiasts.

  • the crowd: Waterloo Region's smart, fun, creative tech community

item.title: UndergroundStudio - Access Wednesdays
item.description:
Date and Time: Wednesday, Apr 19 2017, 6:30pm

Location: THEMUSEUM, Kitchener, ON

http://www.themuseum.ca/access-wednesdays Access Wednesdays

Teaching kids ages 6+ and their parents the skills to make cool things with real tools. Safely.

Using saws, glue guns, hammers and soldering irons, families will explore creativity with tools often reserved for adults. Access Wednesdays run on the second and third Wednesday each month in 2017 from 6:30pm to 8:30pm.

The Underground Studio Access Pass is your way to access The Underground Studio's materials and resources. For a yearly fee of $150 you gain access to twelve unique workshops that are intended to expose children to a wide variety of methods of making. You also receive exclusive discounts to our Underground Studio Camps and Weekend Workshop programs, along with additional access to the space to use items such as our 3D printers.

Interested in trying an Access Wednesday without an Access Pass? Attend a drop-in workshop to try it out! Please pre-register with us at least 7 days prior by sending an email to UndergroundStudio@THEMUSEUM.ca with the subject line Access Wednesdays. Simply let us know your name, how many children will be attending and their names & ages, and the date of the workshop(s) you would like to attend. Each session costs $14+ HST or for a savings of $18 you can purchase an Access Pass. Walk-in registrations on the day of the workshop are not guaranteed due to space availability and supplies.

Level Up: Toy Hacking - December 14/2016 Our Underground Studio will be turned into an island of misfit toys for the month of December. With love, attention, and ingenuity, these toys can be repurposed to create new happy memories. Learn how to deconstruct devices and reconstruct them again in this open-ended experience

Level Up: T-Shirt Silkscreening - January 11/2017 Ink yourself, or rather, fabrics that you own, in this hands-on workshop that introduces the principles of silkscreening. Combine colour, shape, and other elements of design with the knowledge of creating a customized tool just for you!

Level Up: T-Shirt Silkscreening - January 18/2017 Ink yourself, or rather, fabrics that you own, in this hands-on workshop that introduces the principles of silkscreening. Combine colour, shape, and other elements of design with the knowledge of creating a customized tool just for you!

Level Up: Cardboard Automata - February 8/2017 An automaton is a self-operating machine that performs a specific function. We will transform common cardboard into whimsical inventions that function through mechanical means. We will also learn how to work with simple tools like glue guns, box cutters and rotary cutters, as well as the most important tool of all - your mind.

Level Up: Cardboard Automata - February 15/2017 An automaton is a self-operating machine that performs a specific function. We will transform common cardboard into whimsical inventions that function through mechanical means. We will also learn how to work with simple tools like glue guns, box cutters and rotary cutters, as well as the most important tool of all - your mind.

Level Up: Stirling Engine - March 8/2017 Stirling Engines are heat-powered engines that operate within a closed-system. When an external source of heat is applied, the fluid contained expands and pushes a cylinder, driving a flywheel. The air then cools and pushes the cylinder back downward, allowing the process to repeat. We will build a very simple Stirling engine using commonly found household items.

Level Up: Stirling Engine - March 15/2017 Stirling Engines are heat-powered engines that operate within a closed-system. When an external source of heat is applied, the fluid contained expands and pushes a cylinder, driving a flywheel. The air then cools and pushes the cylinder back downward, allowing the process to repeat. We will build a very simple Stirling engine using commonly found household items.

Level Up: Textiles and Tesselations - April 12/2017 Tesselations are patterns that fit really, really well together. Perfectly, in fact! We'll fit regular and exotic shapes together and talk a little bit about the math behind it.

Level Up: Textiles and Tesselations - April 19/2017 Tesselations are patterns that fit really, really well together. Perfectly, in fact! We'll fit regular and exotic shapes together and talk a little bit about the math behind it.

Level Up: Ropemaking - May 10/2017 Though you won't find rope on a list of simple machines, it's an object of immense importance across all civilizations. We'll learn how to make rope and some simple rope-tying techniques.

Level Up: Ropemaking - May 17/2017 Though you won't find rope on a list of simple machines, it's an object of immense importance across all civilizations. We'll learn how to make rope and some simple rope-tying techniques.

Level Up: Robot Guardians - June 14/2017 Using a combination of code, cardboard, and creativity, we'll be constructing our own programming language to teach your family how and why to code.

Level Up: Robot Guardians - June 21/2017 Using a combination of code, cardboard, and creativity, we'll be constructing our own programming language to teach your family how and why to code.

item.title: CCTDNUG: Building a Cloud-Powered Conversation Bot
item.description:
Date and Time: Wednesday, Apr 19 2017, 6:30pm

Location: Kitchener Central Library , 85 Queen St North, Kitchener, Ontario, Canada

https://www.meetup.com/CTTDNUG/events/238244546/ Canada's Technology Triangle .NET User Group

Join us in the evening on Wednesday, April 19th at the Kitchener Central Library, 85 Queen Street North in Meeting Room A for a special session on bots!

Session Details:

With the rise of messaging platforms and digital personal assistants, conversation has become a core UI element and bots have taken over as the new way of interacting with technology. Ranging from simple FAQ bots to advanced human-like conversational AI, chat bots are changing the way we use, view, and build technology. In this technical session, join Microsoft Tech Evangelist Sage Franch to build a cloud-powered bot using Microsoft's Bot Framework and Azure Bot Service. Together we will explore today’s ecosystem of bots, learn how cognitive computing makes bots intelligent, and take a glimpse into the future of everyday AI.

6:00 pm - Doors open

6:30 pm - Session start

About The Speaker: Sage Franch is a Tech Evangelist at Microsoft, motivational speaker, and founder of TrendyTechie.ca. Sage specializes in cloud and emerging technologies including cognitive machines, artificial intelligence, and holographic computing. Prior to becoming a Tech Evangelist, Sage was an educator at Microsoft Learning Experiences, where she created highly technical online training courses for Windows 10 app development. Known internationally as "the Trendy Techie," Sage has been recognized for her volunteer work inspiring youth around the world to explore careers in technology. It is her mission to empower others to build the future. Connect with Sage on Twitter and Instagram, @theTrendyTechie.

item.title: UofW CE - Jesse Zhu: Small Particles Hoisting Gigantic Industrial Processes the Application of Particle Technology in the Real World
item.description:
Date and Time: Thursday, Apr 20 2017, 3:30pm

Location: Engineering 6 (E6-2024), University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON

https://uwaterloo.ca/chemical-engineering/events/seminar-small-particles-hoisting-gigantic-industrial University of Waterloo Chemical Engineering Seminar - “Small Particles Hoisting Gigantic Industrial Processes the Application of Particle Technology in the Real World” by Dr. Jesse Zhu, Distinguished University Professor and Canada Research Chair, The University of Western Ontario, London, ON￼

Thursday, April 20, 2017 3:30 PM EDT

Engineering 6 (E6-2024) University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON

ABSTRACT: Fine particles under 30 microns are very sticky and therefore extremely difficult to handle, due to the stronger interparticle forces, leading to poor powder flowability and fluidization. However, they are also very useful due to their small size and the very large specific surface areas. A nanotechnology has been developed that can significantly enhance fine particle flowability by coating a small fraction of nano particles onto their surfaces.

Using this technology, the speaker's research group has been able to develop a few technologies including an ultrafine powder coating technology, a pulmonary drug delivery technology and a novel powder coating technology for pharmaceutical tablets, some of which have been commercialized or are being commercialized. This talk will review some of the stories behind the technological development and reveal some critical details of the technologies.

Bio-sketch: Dr. Jesse Zhu is a Distinguished University Professor and Canada Research Chair in the Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Western University. He received his PhD from the University of British Columbia and also worked for Shell before joining Western in 1993. In 1999, he established the Particle Technology Research Centre and has served as its Director since then. He is a Fellow of Royal Society of Canada and has received many awards including the highest career award from the Canadian Society for Chemical Engineering and the highest research award from Western University.

Dr. Zhu has many years of experience in the research area of powder handling, fluidized bed and multi-phase flow systems. With 400+ publications, 20+ patents, and over 150 graduate students and postdoctoral fellows supervised, he has worked on a very wide range of R&D projects, many from the industry. In addition to fundamental research, he is particularly active in technology development and transfer, with several inventions commercialized or being commercialized.

Location E6-2024 Canada

item.title: KWLUG Laptop Rescue Mission
item.description:
Date and Time: Saturday, Apr 22 2017, 4:00pm

Location: Computer Recycling (entrance off Charles Street), 56 Queen Street South, Kitchener, Ontario, Canada

https://kwlug.org/node/1092 Kitchener Waterloo Linux Users Group

Every so often a group of KWLUGers volunteers to rescue laptops donated to the Computer Recycling project at The Working Centre. For assorted reasons it is not viable for Computer Recycling to spend much time refurbishing these laptops itself, so we sort through them, select ones in reasonable condition, then install Xubuntu on them for resale.

You are invited to come help! You do not need to be a Linux nerd or a hardware genius to participate: if you can use a screwdriver, read numbers and follow instructions then you can be helpful. There will be lots to learn, but you can learn it as you go along. Linux nerds and hardware geniuses are also welcome to participate, of course.

To participate, please RSVP using the Contact Us functionality on this website: http://kwlug.org/contact Because Computer Recycling is ordinarily closed on Saturdays, you will need special instructions to get into the building.

We will start at around 4pm and end around 8pm, but if you can only come later or have to leave earlier that's fine too.

item.title: Stemotics - LEGO Robotics Workshop for kids
item.description:
Date and Time: Sunday, Apr 23 2017, 11:00am

Location: Stemotics, 1315 Bishop St N, Unit 155, Cambridge, ON

https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/lego-robotics-workshop-for-kids-tickets-29679331680 Stemotics

Cost: $29.99

DESCRIPTION

LEGO WeDo: Learn robotics with LEGO Education WeDo. Build snapping alligators, race cars, and spinning robots, then program them with the WeDo visual drag-and-drop programming software. In this kids robotics course, students are taught engineering basics with an emphasis on exploration and trial and error field-testing. Instead of simply “snapping bricks together,” students are encouraged to think critically about how and why their design needs to adapt to changing conditions. Our guided, personalized instruction allows younger kids to understand more complicated engineering techniques such as gear use, pulleys, and inclined planes.

LEGO Mindstorm EV3: Design awesome machines with the LEGO MINDSTORMS Education EV3 Base Set and Software. Using visual drag-and-drop programming software, build a drag racer that speeds up as you cheer louder or a guard robot that growls at nearby intruders. In this class, students experiment and discover engineering basics via trial and error field testing. Rather than just “snapping bricks together,” students learn critical thinking skills and modify their robot designs based on varying conditions. The course exposes students to more complex engineering techniques such as pulleys, inclined planes, and gear use. Let’s get building! www.stemotics.com

item.title: UofW S&AS - Jeroen De Mast: Mathematical optimization and a multiple-case study
item.description:
Date and Time: Monday, Apr 24 2017, 4:00pm

Location: Mathematics 3 (M3-3127), University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON

https://uwaterloo.ca/statistics-and-actuarial-science/events/department-seminar-jeroen-mast-university-amsterdam University of Waterloo Statistics and Actuarial Science Department Seminar by Jeroen De Mast, University of Amsterdam￼

Monday, April 24, 2017 — 4:00 PM EDT Mathematics 3, University of Waterloo

Mathematical optimization and a multiple-case study Primary and secondary care are offered through outpatient clinics, where patients visit the hospital for a consultation or treatment. Some clinics work on a walk-in basis, but most work with scheduled appointments. Variation in the duration of consultations, random no-shows and walk-ins, and other sources of variability and uncertainty result in waiting time for patients and idle time for the clinician. The challenge, then, is to determine appointment schedules that achieve the best-possible synchronization of the patient’s arrival with the availability of the clinician despite this variability in the process.

  1. Mathematical optimization

There is a large body of research in OR that designs procedures for computing schedules that strike a good balance between expected waiting time for patients and idle time for the clinician. Determining expectations of the waiting and idle time is, in general, analytically intractable, and the challenge is to find effective approximation and simplification techniques. We developed an approach where we approximate the service times by phase-type distributions. These approximate realistic distributions well, and in addition, their properties allow a recursive algorithm to determine the expected waiting and idle times analytically. Standard optimization techniques can be used to compute near-optimal schedules from there.

Next, we show how the approach can be extended in an elegantly simple manner to incorporate no-shows and walk-ins. The procedure outperforms simpler approximations almost uniformly in its precision, and it outperforms approaches based on simulation vastly in computation time and ease of use.

  1. Multiple-case study

The way in which the problem of appointment scheduling is usually framed in mathematical optimization approaches has very meager substantiation, neither from theory in operations management, nor from field studies analyzing the objectives and challenges in real healthcare operations. We conducted a multiple-case study, conducted in 10 clinics, aimed at two research questions:

What is the structure of the problem of appointment scheduling in outpatient clinics? What are current practices and underlying assumptions and conceptualizations in the field?

Based on the results, we propose that there are better ways to address the problem than scheduling, and these reflect modern approaches for production management in industry. Rather than absorbing the effects of variability in buffers of waiting and idle time, it is better to pursue that variability is reduced, and to absorb the remaining variability by flexibility of clinicians and other resources. Moreover, given the complexity and dynamic behavior of service processes in outpatient clinics, we recommend optimization approaches based on feedback adjustment, instead of the currently studied approaches based on optimal design.

Location M3 - Mathematics 3 Room 3127 200 University Avenue West Waterloo, ON N2L 3G1 Canada

item.title: D2L Night School - Bob Duncan: Crafting Delightful Experiences with Microinteractions
item.description:
Date and Time: Monday, Apr 24 2017, 6:30pm

Location: D2l, 151 Chariles St W, Kitchener, ON

https://www.meetup.com/D2L-Night-School/events/238664558/ D2L Night School Crafting Delightful Experiences with Microinteractions featuring Bob Duncan

Monday, April 24, 2017 6:30 PM to 8:30 PM

D2L 151 Charles St, Kitchener, ON

What makes iOS and Android so enjoyable to use? Why do people find delight in completing complex functions on their smartphone? Why has mobile set the bar for delightful user experiences? Enter microinteractions.

Microinteractions are single use interactions such as: - Setting an alarm - Changing your home's temperature - Liking a post on Facebook

They go un-noticed until something goes horribly wrong (as does all good design); Microinteractions set the foundation for delight and usability in web applications, mobile apps, and even household appliances.

We're going to review the key ingredients of micro interactions. I'll share some examples of successful microinteractions and how they've shaped the products they live in. We'll discuss process and how you can include micro interactions in your workflow.

Bob Duncan is a passionate Product Designer located in sunny Winnipeg Canada.

With more than ten years designing for the digital world, he takes pride in simplifying complex problems to create intuitive, beautiful user experiences.

Bob is confident designing web and mobile applications. As a user centered designer, he enjoys quick iteration loops with users to validate his problem hypothesis and design solutions.

In addition to crafting design solutions, Bob is passionate about growing the design community in Winnipeg and beyond. He is the founder of the Interaction Design Association of Winnipeg and teaches User Experience part time.

Join us at D2L at 151 Charles St West in the Tannery on Monday, April 24 from 6:30 to 8:30pm. Take the elevator to the 3rd floor where a D2Ler will greet you. This is a free event that is open to the public. RSVP today on Meetup.

Free parking is available in the Tannery parking lot. We will have local craft beer and snacks available.

item.title: UofW Distinguished Lecture Series: Eric Horvitz - Data, Predictions and Decisions in Support of People and Society
item.description:
Date and Time: Thursday, Apr 27 2017, 3:30pm

Location: Davis Centre 1302, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, Canada

https://math.uwaterloo.ca/computer-science/events/dls-eric-horvitz-data-predictions-and-decisions-support-people-and-society University of Waterloo Cheriton School of Computer Science

DLS: Eric Horvitz - Data, Predictions and Decisions in Support of People and Society

Eric Horvitz, Technical Fellow and Managing Director, Microsoft Research—Redmond Lab

Abstract:

I will share directions and results enabled by the confluence of large-scale data resources, jumps in computational power, and advances in machine intelligence. I will focus on efforts that leverage learning and inference to help people with decisions, covering work in transportation, healthcare, and interactive systems. I will present projects that draw from traditional sources of data, such as GPS signals and electronic health records, as well as efforts that harness more exotic streams of information, including the use of planes in flight and anonymized behavioral data drawn from web services. I will conclude by discussing the promise of leveraging data, learning, and reasoning to enable new kinds of collaboration between people and machines to address challenges in the sciences, society, and daily life.

Biography:

Eric Horvitz is a technical fellow and director of the Microsoft Research lab at Redmond. He has pursued principles and applications of artificial intelligence, with contributions in decisions under uncertainty, machine learning, bounded rationality, information retrieval, and human computation. His research and collaborations have led to fielded systems in healthcare, transportation, human-computer interaction, operating systems, ecommerce, and robotics. He has been elected fellow of the National Academy of Engineering, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the Association for the Advancement of AI (AAAI), the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), and the Association for Computing Machinery. He received the Feigenbaum Prize and the ACM-AAAI Allen Newell Award for his research contributions. He has served as president of the AAAI, chair of the AAAS Section on Information, Computing, and Communications, and on advisory committees for the National Institutes of Health, the National Science Foundation, the Computer Science and Telecommunications Board, DARPA, and the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology. More information can be found at http://research.microsoft.com/~horvitz.

Distinguished Lecture Series

Location DC - William G. Davis Computer Research Centre 1302 200 University Avenue West Waterloo, ON N2L 3G1 Canada

item.title: UofW PA - D. A. Drabold: Computational Design of Materials
item.description:
Date and Time: Thursday, Apr 27 2017, 4:00pm

Location: Physics (PHY-308), University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON

https://uwaterloo.ca/physics-astronomy/events/computational-design-materials University of Waterloo Physics and Astronomy Computational Design of Materials￼

Thursday, April 27, 2017 — 4:00 PM EDT

￼D. A. Drabold ​Distinguished Professor Department of Physics & Astronomy, Ohio University

David Alan Drabold works on the theory of condensed matter. His work has focused particularly on the physics of amorphous materials, including glasses. In addition to creating realistic computer models of these materials, he has contributed significantly to our understanding of the consequences of structural disorder to electronic, optical and transport properties. He has also developed a number of new computational algorithms for the efficient and accurate simulation of these and other materials using approaches based upon the foundation of quantum mechanics.

￼ABSTRACT Conventional modeling of complex materials usually proceeds by some form of direct atomistic simulation, such at Monte Carlo or Molecular Dynamics, which is often intended to mimic an experimental growth process. In such a simulation, no use is made of a priori information. Often, we possess information from experiments about the materials, or we may wish to design a novel material with a desired property. In this talk, I discuss strategies to build in experimental data as a constraint in the modeling[1], and also a scheme to impose optical properties (say, opening or closing the optical gap [2]). The latter method has made it possible to create electronically designed phases of amorphous carbon and silicon using tight-binding molecular dynamics, and with extension to ab initio schemes, to discover the conducting phase of a silver-doped chalcogenide “Conducting Bridge” FLASH memory material[3].

References [1] A. Pandey, P. Biswas and D. A. Drabold, Phys Rev B 92 155205 (2015). [2] K. Prasai, P. Biswas and D. A. Drabold, Sci. Rep. 5 15522 (2015). [3]K. Prasai, G. Chen and D. A. Drabold, https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.02838

Location: PHY - Physics 308 200 University Avenue West Waterloo, ON N2L 3G1 Canada

item.description:

https://www.meetup.com/Internet-of-Things-Waterloo/events/238090660/ Internet of Things Waterloo

Thursday, April 27, 2017 6:00 PM

Shopify Plus 57 Erb St W, Waterloo, ON

Bjorn Dawson
co-founder and CEO - Grobo

Grobo is a technology company that designs beautiful and easy-to-use home plant growing systems. Bjorn is a serial entrepreneur with a passion for growing plants and has a background in Mechanical Engineering.

When not in his garden, Bjorn can be found reading, traveling, or hardware hacking.

Grobo was created to seamlessly merge the latest growing technologies, making it easy for everyone to achieve quick and high yield grows. Grobo is based out of Waterloo.

Uche Onuora Co-Founder at HITCH

HITCH – an enhanced smart wireless mesh router that enables communities automatically build, operate, and sustain self-contained Internet platforms; accelerating sustainable broadband in emerging markets. HITCH is a smart hardware product (a WiFi router – with embedded storage, processing, and solar/battery capacity) AND software service (proprietary algorithms running on each router), that (connecting to other HITCH routers) forms local decentralized cloud platforms for storing, sharing, and updating Internet Content, Services, and Applications.

Each user’s smart router automatically interconnects with neighboring users’ routers to form wireless community networks. These community broadband platforms enable connections from users with any WiFi-enabled device; to access videos, talk/chat with each other, or use other relevant apps, with or without Internet connectivity.

item.title: KW-RASC - Stargazing 101
item.description:
Date and Time: Friday, Apr 28 2017, 7:00pm

Location: Zehrs, Laurentian Power Centre, 750 Ottawa St S, Kitchener, ON

http://kw.rasc.ca/Stargazing101/?page=meetings

The Stargazing 101 group was formed by K-W RASC members to provide a forum for people new to the hobby of astronomy and to promote visual observation. The group is open to the public, but if your interest is genuine the benefits of joining the K-W RASC will soon become apparent. We have a dark observing site and some telescopes available to qualified members.

item.title: KWLUG: Aden Seaman - Introduction to Functional Programming and Haskell
item.description:
Date and Time: Monday, May 01 2017, 6:30pm

Location: St. John's Kitchen, 97 Victoria Avenue North, Kitchener, Ontario, Canada

https://kwlug.org/node/1078 Kitchener Waterloo Linux Users Group

Aden Seaman will give us an introduction to functional programming. He will cover the following topics:

What functional programming is all about, and how it differs from imperative programming. Commonalities and differences between Erlang, Scala, Clojure and Haskell. A deeper exploration of Haskell, including its famous type system, functional purity, laziness. Implications of the type system on language safety, programming style and constraints, and concurrent programming.

===== http://kwlug.org/upcoming/

The Kitchener-Waterloo Linux User Group is a monthly meeting of GNU/Linux, Free Software, Open Source and technology enthusiasts. We meet in Kitchener, Ontario, usually on the first (non-holiday) Monday of the month. Our meetings are free and open to those with an interest in Linux. Find out more about our meetings. Join our mailing lists.

Setup/pre-meeting: 6pm
Formal meeting start: 7pm
Post meeting: 9pm

The pre-meeting is informal and very loosely structured. This is an opportunity form small group discussions. At times we may have a brief video presentation as well. Informal question and answer sessions regarding your specific projects are welcome.

The formal part of the meeting is not really very formal at all; we have no requirement for tuxedoes or evening wear. But we do try to give informative presentations during the formal meeting. This will include a few technical presentations by our members. The topics are as varied as our members and have included everything from games to finance, from graphics to file systems, databases to word processors, from spam filtering to telephone answering machines from servers to clients, from hither to yon. If you find any of this confusing, don't worry, we have question and answer sessions too!

After the meeting and a quick clean-up, some of us will go to a local restaurant for further discussion and snacks. Make sure to ask us for details if you plan to join us.

Meetings are free and open to those with an interest in Linux. All levels of Linux experience are welcome at our meetings. You are welcome if you have heard about Linux and are curious to learn more. Come on out and meet us. See our locations page to find out where to go.

item.title: UndergroundStudio - Access Wednesdays
item.description:
Date and Time: Wednesday, May 10 2017, 6:30pm

Location: THEMUSEUM, Kitchener, ON

http://www.themuseum.ca/access-wednesdays Access Wednesdays

Teaching kids ages 6+ and their parents the skills to make cool things with real tools. Safely.

Using saws, glue guns, hammers and soldering irons, families will explore creativity with tools often reserved for adults. Access Wednesdays run on the second and third Wednesday each month in 2017 from 6:30pm to 8:30pm.

The Underground Studio Access Pass is your way to access The Underground Studio's materials and resources. For a yearly fee of $150 you gain access to twelve unique workshops that are intended to expose children to a wide variety of methods of making. You also receive exclusive discounts to our Underground Studio Camps and Weekend Workshop programs, along with additional access to the space to use items such as our 3D printers.

Interested in trying an Access Wednesday without an Access Pass? Attend a drop-in workshop to try it out! Please pre-register with us at least 7 days prior by sending an email to UndergroundStudio@THEMUSEUM.ca with the subject line Access Wednesdays. Simply let us know your name, how many children will be attending and their names & ages, and the date of the workshop(s) you would like to attend. Each session costs $14+ HST or for a savings of $18 you can purchase an Access Pass. Walk-in registrations on the day of the workshop are not guaranteed due to space availability and supplies.

Level Up: Toy Hacking - December 14/2016 Our Underground Studio will be turned into an island of misfit toys for the month of December. With love, attention, and ingenuity, these toys can be repurposed to create new happy memories. Learn how to deconstruct devices and reconstruct them again in this open-ended experience

Level Up: T-Shirt Silkscreening - January 11/2017 Ink yourself, or rather, fabrics that you own, in this hands-on workshop that introduces the principles of silkscreening. Combine colour, shape, and other elements of design with the knowledge of creating a customized tool just for you!

Level Up: T-Shirt Silkscreening - January 18/2017 Ink yourself, or rather, fabrics that you own, in this hands-on workshop that introduces the principles of silkscreening. Combine colour, shape, and other elements of design with the knowledge of creating a customized tool just for you!

Level Up: Cardboard Automata - February 8/2017 An automaton is a self-operating machine that performs a specific function. We will transform common cardboard into whimsical inventions that function through mechanical means. We will also learn how to work with simple tools like glue guns, box cutters and rotary cutters, as well as the most important tool of all - your mind.

Level Up: Cardboard Automata - February 15/2017 An automaton is a self-operating machine that performs a specific function. We will transform common cardboard into whimsical inventions that function through mechanical means. We will also learn how to work with simple tools like glue guns, box cutters and rotary cutters, as well as the most important tool of all - your mind.

Level Up: Stirling Engine - March 8/2017 Stirling Engines are heat-powered engines that operate within a closed-system. When an external source of heat is applied, the fluid contained expands and pushes a cylinder, driving a flywheel. The air then cools and pushes the cylinder back downward, allowing the process to repeat. We will build a very simple Stirling engine using commonly found household items.

Level Up: Stirling Engine - March 15/2017 Stirling Engines are heat-powered engines that operate within a closed-system. When an external source of heat is applied, the fluid contained expands and pushes a cylinder, driving a flywheel. The air then cools and pushes the cylinder back downward, allowing the process to repeat. We will build a very simple Stirling engine using commonly found household items.

Level Up: Textiles and Tesselations - April 12/2017 Tesselations are patterns that fit really, really well together. Perfectly, in fact! We'll fit regular and exotic shapes together and talk a little bit about the math behind it.

Level Up: Textiles and Tesselations - April 19/2017 Tesselations are patterns that fit really, really well together. Perfectly, in fact! We'll fit regular and exotic shapes together and talk a little bit about the math behind it.

Level Up: Ropemaking - May 10/2017 Though you won't find rope on a list of simple machines, it's an object of immense importance across all civilizations. We'll learn how to make rope and some simple rope-tying techniques.

Level Up: Ropemaking - May 17/2017 Though you won't find rope on a list of simple machines, it's an object of immense importance across all civilizations. We'll learn how to make rope and some simple rope-tying techniques.

Level Up: Robot Guardians - June 14/2017 Using a combination of code, cardboard, and creativity, we'll be constructing our own programming language to teach your family how and why to code.

Level Up: Robot Guardians - June 21/2017 Using a combination of code, cardboard, and creativity, we'll be constructing our own programming language to teach your family how and why to code.

item.title: UofW EQUALS Conference: Excellence and Quality in Academic Life in STEM
item.description:
Date and Time: Thursday, May 11 2017, 8:30am

Location: University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON

https://uwaterloo.ca/excellence-quality-academic-life/ The University of Waterloo is hosting the Excellence and Quality of Academic Life in STEM (EQUALS) conference this May 11-12, 2017 in Waterloo, Ontario, Canada.

EQUALS is a venue for graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and young scholars considering an academic career in a Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) field. The purpose of this conference is to explore the spectrum of pathways of academic success in STEM with an explicit focus on gender equity and its intersections with other identity markers.

Highlights include:

Keynotes by Dr. Lesley Yellowlees, University of Edinburgh and Dr. Lesley Shannon, Simon Fraser University
Workshops on strategic networking, academic interviewing, and work-life balance
Presentation by Ontario’s Pay Equity Commissioner on salary negotiation

Are you a graduate student, postdoc or young scholar considering an academic career in a science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) field? Join us to explore the spectrum of pathways of academic success in STEM with an explicit focus on gender equity and its intersections with other identity markers.

Network with like-minded scholars to form supportive academic communities and connections with academic mentors. Sessions will focus on issues related to the under-representation of women-identifying aspiring scholars in the STEM fields, associated challenges in academia and identification of potential practical solutions and career advice for women.

Participation is open to all genders. Everyone interested in these issues is welcome to attend. This will be a safe space for open discussion of identity-based challenges faced by those interested in pursuing a career in academia in STEM fields. To affect a real and meaningful change in the STEM academic climate, the EQUALS conference is dedicated to having attendees of diverse genders, races, minority groups, ethnic backgrounds and academic career paths.

The registration deadline is March 31, 2017 at 11:59pm.

item.title: UofW AM - Mary-Louise Timmermans: Summer heat overwinters in the Arctic Ocean
item.description:
Date and Time: Thursday, May 11 2017, 2:30pm

Location: Mathematics and Computer (MC-6460), University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON

https://uwaterloo.ca/applied-mathematics/events/applied-mathematics-colloquium-mary-louise-timmermans-summer University of Waterloo Applied Mathematics Applied Mathematics Colloquium | Mary-Louise Timmermans, Summer heat overwinters in the Arctic Ocean

Thursday, May 11, 2017 — 2:30 PM EDT MC 6460

Speaker Professor Mary-Louise Timmermans Yale University

Title Summer heat overwinters in the Arctic Ocean

Abstract The talk will address the implications of a warming Arctic Ocean on the overlying sea-ice cover. In recent years, atypically warm water layers have been observed at depth in the Arctic Ocean. These derive from intense summertime solar heating in expansive ice-free regions. Heat that is stored in the shallow ocean can be released in the fall and winter by shear-driven mixing, and convective mixing by the release of dense plumes during sea-ice growth, reducing the net sea-ice growth. On the other hand, deeper warm ocean layers remain unaffected. I'll show that under continued warming, there exists the possibility for a regime shift in ocean ventilation by these warm waters, and a subsequent cap on the storage of deep-ocean heat.

item.title: Tinker Truck - Maker Club Cambridge
item.description:
Date and Time: Thursday, May 11 2017, 6:30pm

Location: Playfit Kids Club, 366 Hespeler Rd, Cambridge, ON

http://tinkertruck.ca/maker-club-cambridge/ Tinker Truck Maker Club Cambridge!

NEWS! Our newest Maker Club started up in Cambridge at PlayFit Kids Club in 2017. Building on the experience and strengths of the Kitchener club at THEMUSEUM we’ve decided to expand the availability to a wider audience and a new city. You can find the details below or sign up for our newsletter to keep informed.

In general, the goal of MakerClub is to explore creativity using tools that children often do not get to play with. We use saws, glue guns, hammers and soldering irons to make something interesting each month. In the process we teach our kids how to work with these tools safely and respectfully. Parents are required to stay, learn, and participate in the program so that they can foster inventiveness and makerly explorations at home between meetings. We require at least one adult per two children for new maker club members. As the month’s pass and skills grow we can discuss relaxing this ratio on an individual basis.

Upcoming Maker Club meetings in Cambridge:

Thursday, February 9th – 6:30-8pm – Toy Hacking Thursday, March 9th – 6:30-8pm – LED Artwork Thursday, April 13th – 6:30-8pm – Make your own TShirt Thursday, May 11th – 6:30-8pm – LED Slingshot Helicopters (bring outdoor clothes) Thursday, June 8th – 6:30-8pm – Foam Air Rockets Thursday, July 13th – 6:30-8pm – Portable River Experiments Thursday, August 10th – 6:30-8pm – Marshmallow Mayhem Thursday, September 14th – 6:30-8pm – 3D Printing and Modelling (bring your own Laptop) October, November and December topics to be selected by regular participants. The cost for this program is $20/child per evening. Parents are free. Indoor Playground time is available and included in this price starting at 5pm (bring a second adult and siblings in the playground are $5+tax all night). A quarterly Maker Club Cambridge membership is available for $50 for three (3) consecutive months if paid before your first month.

There is a limit of 20 children per class, so please be sure to book in advance.

item.title: Stemotics - LEGO Robotics Workshop for kids
item.description:
Date and Time: Sunday, May 14 2017, 11:00am

Location: Stemotics, 1315 Bishop St N, Unit 155, Cambridge, ON

https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/lego-robotics-workshop-for-kids-tickets-29679331680 Stemotics

Cost: $29.99

DESCRIPTION

LEGO WeDo: Learn robotics with LEGO Education WeDo. Build snapping alligators, race cars, and spinning robots, then program them with the WeDo visual drag-and-drop programming software. In this kids robotics course, students are taught engineering basics with an emphasis on exploration and trial and error field-testing. Instead of simply “snapping bricks together,” students are encouraged to think critically about how and why their design needs to adapt to changing conditions. Our guided, personalized instruction allows younger kids to understand more complicated engineering techniques such as gear use, pulleys, and inclined planes.

LEGO Mindstorm EV3: Design awesome machines with the LEGO MINDSTORMS Education EV3 Base Set and Software. Using visual drag-and-drop programming software, build a drag racer that speeds up as you cheer louder or a guard robot that growls at nearby intruders. In this class, students experiment and discover engineering basics via trial and error field testing. Rather than just “snapping bricks together,” students learn critical thinking skills and modify their robot designs based on varying conditions. The course exposes students to more complex engineering techniques such as pulleys, inclined planes, and gear use. Let’s get building! www.stemotics.com

item.title: KW Go Devs - Simon Pratt: The Go Assembler
item.description:
Date and Time: Tuesday, May 16 2017, 7:00pm

Location: Dejero, 412 Albert St, Waterloo, ON

https://www.meetup.com/Golang-KW/events/239155918/ KW Go Developers The Go Assembler

Tuesday, May 16, 2017 7:00 PM

Dejero 412 Albert St., Waterloo, ON

Simon Pratt will be presenting Go's assembler. He'll explain the Go compilation process; why Go uses its own, machine-independent, assembly language; how it's different from other assembly languages; how it's different from other intermediate languages like GCC's GENERIC/GIMPLE/RTL or LLVM's IR; and why it's useful to know about Go's underlying tool chain.

item.title: UndergroundStudio - Access Wednesdays
item.description:
Date and Time: Wednesday, May 17 2017, 6:30pm

Location: THEMUSEUM, Kitchener, ON

http://www.themuseum.ca/access-wednesdays Access Wednesdays

Teaching kids ages 6+ and their parents the skills to make cool things with real tools. Safely.

Using saws, glue guns, hammers and soldering irons, families will explore creativity with tools often reserved for adults. Access Wednesdays run on the second and third Wednesday each month in 2017 from 6:30pm to 8:30pm.

The Underground Studio Access Pass is your way to access The Underground Studio's materials and resources. For a yearly fee of $150 you gain access to twelve unique workshops that are intended to expose children to a wide variety of methods of making. You also receive exclusive discounts to our Underground Studio Camps and Weekend Workshop programs, along with additional access to the space to use items such as our 3D printers.

Interested in trying an Access Wednesday without an Access Pass? Attend a drop-in workshop to try it out! Please pre-register with us at least 7 days prior by sending an email to UndergroundStudio@THEMUSEUM.ca with the subject line Access Wednesdays. Simply let us know your name, how many children will be attending and their names & ages, and the date of the workshop(s) you would like to attend. Each session costs $14+ HST or for a savings of $18 you can purchase an Access Pass. Walk-in registrations on the day of the workshop are not guaranteed due to space availability and supplies.

Level Up: Toy Hacking - December 14/2016 Our Underground Studio will be turned into an island of misfit toys for the month of December. With love, attention, and ingenuity, these toys can be repurposed to create new happy memories. Learn how to deconstruct devices and reconstruct them again in this open-ended experience

Level Up: T-Shirt Silkscreening - January 11/2017 Ink yourself, or rather, fabrics that you own, in this hands-on workshop that introduces the principles of silkscreening. Combine colour, shape, and other elements of design with the knowledge of creating a customized tool just for you!

Level Up: T-Shirt Silkscreening - January 18/2017 Ink yourself, or rather, fabrics that you own, in this hands-on workshop that introduces the principles of silkscreening. Combine colour, shape, and other elements of design with the knowledge of creating a customized tool just for you!

Level Up: Cardboard Automata - February 8/2017 An automaton is a self-operating machine that performs a specific function. We will transform common cardboard into whimsical inventions that function through mechanical means. We will also learn how to work with simple tools like glue guns, box cutters and rotary cutters, as well as the most important tool of all - your mind.

Level Up: Cardboard Automata - February 15/2017 An automaton is a self-operating machine that performs a specific function. We will transform common cardboard into whimsical inventions that function through mechanical means. We will also learn how to work with simple tools like glue guns, box cutters and rotary cutters, as well as the most important tool of all - your mind.

Level Up: Stirling Engine - March 8/2017 Stirling Engines are heat-powered engines that operate within a closed-system. When an external source of heat is applied, the fluid contained expands and pushes a cylinder, driving a flywheel. The air then cools and pushes the cylinder back downward, allowing the process to repeat. We will build a very simple Stirling engine using commonly found household items.

Level Up: Stirling Engine - March 15/2017 Stirling Engines are heat-powered engines that operate within a closed-system. When an external source of heat is applied, the fluid contained expands and pushes a cylinder, driving a flywheel. The air then cools and pushes the cylinder back downward, allowing the process to repeat. We will build a very simple Stirling engine using commonly found household items.

Level Up: Textiles and Tesselations - April 12/2017 Tesselations are patterns that fit really, really well together. Perfectly, in fact! We'll fit regular and exotic shapes together and talk a little bit about the math behind it.

Level Up: Textiles and Tesselations - April 19/2017 Tesselations are patterns that fit really, really well together. Perfectly, in fact! We'll fit regular and exotic shapes together and talk a little bit about the math behind it.

Level Up: Ropemaking - May 10/2017 Though you won't find rope on a list of simple machines, it's an object of immense importance across all civilizations. We'll learn how to make rope and some simple rope-tying techniques.

Level Up: Ropemaking - May 17/2017 Though you won't find rope on a list of simple machines, it's an object of immense importance across all civilizations. We'll learn how to make rope and some simple rope-tying techniques.

Level Up: Robot Guardians - June 14/2017 Using a combination of code, cardboard, and creativity, we'll be constructing our own programming language to teach your family how and why to code.

Level Up: Robot Guardians - June 21/2017 Using a combination of code, cardboard, and creativity, we'll be constructing our own programming language to teach your family how and why to code.

http://groups.drupal.org/waterloo-region

A group for Drupal users in southern Ontario, serving Cambridge, Guelph, Kitchener, Waterloo and surrounding areas. Who

All Drupal enthusiasts are welcome to join us for discussion and demonstration of topics for beginners and beyond. What

Topics range from implementation examples and demonstrations to tutorials and workshops to round-tables, question and answers and panel discussions. When

Meetings are held monthly and are free of charge. They happen on the third Thursday of each month, 19:00 to 21:00. Where

The Working Centre at 58 Queen St. S. Kitchener, Ontario.

Note that there are two addresses with "The Working Centre" sign on them. Be sure to go to 58 and not the other one.
